<p> ElevationGrid is a geometry node defining a rectangular height field, with default values for a 1m by 1m square at height 0. Vertices corresponding to ElevationGrid height values define quadrilaterals, which are placed above or below a flat surface. <i>Hint:</i> the height array defines (xDimension-1)*(zDimension-1) quadrilaterals. </p> <p> X3D Tooltips of interest: <a href="https://www.web3d.org/x3d/content/X3dTooltips.html#ElevationGrid" target="_blank">ElevationGrid</a>. </p> <p> <a href="https://www.web3d.org/documents/specifications/19775-1/V3.3/Part01/Architecture.html" target="_blank">X3D Specification</a> sections of interest: <a href="https://www.web3d.org/documents/specifications/19775-1/V3.3/Part01/components/geometry3D.html" target="_blank">13 Geometry3D component</a>, <a href="https://www.web3d.org/documents/specifications/19775-1/V3.3/Part01/components/geometry3D.html#Concepts" target="_blank">13.2 Concepts</a> and <a href="https://www.web3d.org/documents/specifications/19775-1/V3.3/Part01/components/geometry3D.html#ElevationGrid" target="_blank">13.3.4 ElevationGrid</a>. </p> <p> <a href="https://www.web3d.org/x3d/content/examples/X3dResources.html#Examples" target="_blank">X3D Examples Archives</a> of related interest: </p> <ul> <li> VRML 2 Sourcebook:&nbsp; <a href="https://www.web3d.org/x3d/content/examples/Vrml2Sourcebook/Chapter14ElevationGrid" target="_blank">Chapter 14 Elevation Grid</a> </li> <li> X3D for Web Authors: <a href="http://x3dgraphics.com/examples/X3dForWebAuthors/Chapter06GeometryPointsLinesPolygons" target="_blank">Chapter 06 Geometry Points Lines Polygons</a> </li> </ul>
